_exec_summary.SummaryText:
A.  Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies:
At the Kaneka Texas Pasadena facility, there are five chemicals covered by the EPA¿s RMP regulation (40 CFR Part 68).  They are: Acrylonitrile, 1-3 Butadiene, Chlorine, Butanes and Propylene Oxide.  It is vital to observe certain safety precautions in handling these chemicals to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to personal health and safety of ourselves, our co-workers, our contractors, the community and our environment.  It is our policy to adhere to all Federal and state rules and regulations.  Safety depends on the manner in which we handle these chemicals combined with the safety devices inherent in the design of our facility, as well as the safe handling procedures that we use to train our personnel.
The facility maintains an emergency response plan that defines the steps the facility and each employee should take during an accidental release of a regulated substance.  The plan includes both evacuation and protective action procedures for employees not directly involved in the response, and actions to be taken by employees responsible for responding to and mitigating the release.  All employees are trained in the applicable emergency response procedures.  Drills and exercises are routinely conducted to test the facility¿s plans and revise the plans if necessary. 
The emergency response plan also includes procedures for notifying facility personnel, including emergency response personnel, the local Channels Industry Mutual Aid (CIMA) agency, the Community Awareness Emergency Response (CAER) organization and the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  
B.  The stationary source and regulated substances handled:
Kaneka Corporation engages in the manufacturing of synthetic resins, plastic products, chemicals and electrical raw materials and synthetic fibers. Its products include MBS (modifier resin) resin, used to improve the shock, weather, and heat resistance of various

types of plastic; base polymer for modified silicone sealant, used as sealing material for construction; polyolefin foam beads, a molding method, using pre-foamed beads, to manufacture polyethylene foam.
The Kaneka Texas Pasadena facility is one stationary source with four distinct operating units.  Two units, Modifiers and Eperan, are operational.  The third, Chlorinated-polyvinylchloride (CPVC), is under construction with an expected startup date in early 2008.  The final unit, Modified Silicones (MSA), is still under design and has a proposed startup date of 2009.  This RMPlan includes all four units as the quantities, process conditions and locations of all covered chemicals are known at this time.  
 
The Modifiers unit handles two RMP-covered chemicals: 
¿  1, 3-Butadiene (flammable) with a maximum inventory of 301,000 lbs; and
¿  Acrylonitrile (toxic) with a maximum inventory of 132,000 lbs.
The primary purpose of the butadiene and acrylonitrile are as raw materials to create a polymer which is blended with plastics, such as PVC, for impact improvement, as well as applications for window frames and siding.
The Eperan unit handles one RMP-covered chemical: 
¿  Butanes (flammable) with a maximum inventory of 56,400 lbs.
Butanes are used to expand polypropylene and polyethylene beads which are then used in molding applications.
CPVC handles one chemical: 
¿  Chlorine (toxic) with a maximum possible inventory of 180,000 lbs.
Chlorine is reacted in a water slurry with the PVC.  The resultant CPVC powder is conveyed to railcar for shipping.  CPVC is used in the manufacturing of hot water plastic pipes.  
MSA handles one chemical:
¿  Propylene oxide (toxic) with a maximum possible inventory of 220,500 lbs.
Propylene Oxide (PO) is brought onsite by tank truck and reacted with other organic chemicals to make a modified silicone liquid.  The end product is used in the manufacturing of sealants.
The Pasadena facility is equipped to safely unload tank trucks and railcar

s into storage vessels.  Access to the site is restricted to authorized facility personnel, management and contractors.
C.  The worst-case release scenarios and the alternative release scenarios
There are five chemicals located at Kaneka that meet or exceed the threshold quantity as defined in RMP.  There are three toxic chemicals (Acylonitrile, Chlorine and Propylene Oxide) and two flammables (1,3-Butadiene and Butanes).  
Acrylonitrile
The worst case scenario for Acrylonitrile involves a release of 132,000 lbs from a storage vessel into a 2,600 sq-ft dike.  The toxic liquid was released at a temperature of 103°F which is highest daily temperature in the last 3-year period.  RMP Comp was used to predict a distance of 1.2 miles to the 0.76 mg/L endpoint.  
The alternative release scenario for Acrylonitrile involves a 2-inch leak from the storage vessel into the 2,600 sq-ft dike.  A release rate of 112 lb/min over 1,170 minutes was used to represent the evaporation of the liquid Acrylonitrile.  RMP Comp was used to predict a distance of 0.4 miles to the 0.76 mg/L endpoint.  No credit was taken for active mitigation (e.g., foam suppression), although it is available.
1, 3-Butadiene
The worst case scenario for 1, 3-Butadiene involves a release of 301,000 lbs of flammable vapor from a storage vessel with a resulting vapor cloud explosion.  RMP Comp was used to predict a distance of 0.5 miles to the 1 psi endpoint.  
The alternative release scenario for 1, 3-Butadiene involves a release from a truck of 45,000 lbs through a 2-inch unloading hose with resulting vapor cloud explosion.  RMP Comp was used to predict a distance of 0.1 miles to the 1 psi endpoint.  No credit was taken for either passive or active mitigation (e.g., foam suppression), although it is available.
Chlorine
The worst case scenario for Chlorine involves a release of 180,000 lbs of pressurized liquid from a railcar.  The toxic liquid was released at a rate of 18,000 lb/min for 10 minutes.  Guidance prov

ided by the Chlorine Institute (Pamphlet 74) was used to predict a distance of 25 miles to the 0.0087 mg/L endpoint.  
The alternative release scenario for Chlorine involves a 90-ton railcar relief valve opening for 30 minutes.  The toxic liquid was released at a rate of 141 lb/min.   Guidance provided by the Chlorine Institute (Pamphlet 74) was used to predict a distance of 1.9 miles to the 0.0087 mg/L endpoint.  No credit was taken for active mitigation (e.g., foam suppression), although it is available.
Butanes
The worst case scenario for Butanes involves a release of 56,400 lbs of flammable vapor from a storage vessel with a resulting vapor cloud explosion.  RMP Comp was used to predict a distance of 0.3 miles to the 1 psi endpoint.  
The alternative release scenario for Butanes involves a release from a truck of 6,000 lbs through a 2-inch unloading hose with resulting vapor cloud explosion.  RMP Comp was used to predict a distance of 0.08 miles to the 1 psi endpoint.  No credit was taken for either passive or active mitigation (e.g., foam suppression), although it is available.
Propylene Oxide
The worst case scenario for Propylene Oxide involves a release of 220,500 lbs of liquid from a storage vessel.  The toxic liquid was released at a rate of 237 lb/min for 931 minutes.  RMP Comp was used to predict a distance of 1.2 miles to the 0.59 mg/L endpoint.  
The alternative release scenario for Propylene Oxide involves a 2-inch leak from the storage vessel into the 1,302 sq-ft dike.  A release rate of 291 lb/min over 764 minutes was used to represent the evaporation of the liquid.  RMP Comp was used to predict a distance of 0.2 miles to the 0.59 mg/L endpoint.  No credit was taken for active mitigation (e.g., foam suppression), although it is available.
D.  General accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps:
The Kaneka facility is a PSM-covered facility and, as such, it has a viable and robust process safety program.  
Process Haza

rds Analyses have been conducted on processes containing all four RMP-covered chemicals.  Major hazards identified include fire, explosion, toxic chemical releases, overpressurization, overfilling, and equipment failure.  Process controls in place include relief valves, emergency and automatic shutdowns, grounding, interlocks and procedures and training.  Additionally, Acrylonitrile, Chlorine and Propylene Oxide storage are contained within dikes with appropriate drainage and fire protection.  Fire protection is also provided for areas containing the flammables Butane and 1, 3-Butadiene.  
Training is conducted continuously and includes classroom, on-the-job mentoring and standard operating procedure (SOP) reviews.  Testing and demonstration are used as means to verify understanding.  SOPs are kept evergreen through a continuous review and revision process that is managed by designated individuals in each process unit.
The site has both predictive and preventative maintenance programs which include inspections, tests and routine maintenance activities that are performed by trained and competent employees and contractors.  Inspection and testing frequencies are prescribed by manufacturers and industry standards.  There is a system in place to correct identified deficiencies.  Additionally, there is a quality assurance program in place which reviews individual workmanship as well as new and spare parts.
Change is managed through a management-of-change (MOC) process.  The MOC process outlines approval responsibilities and requires hazard evaluations prior to the implementation of any changes affecting a covered process.  Affected personnel and contractors are trained in the changes before they startup.  Additionally, changes undergo a pre-startup safety review conducted by appropriate employees, as spelled out in the facility¿s Pre-startup Safety Review procedure.
A PSM and RMP compliance audit was conducted in October, 2007.  Findings were discussed with the facility¿

s management team and personnel were assigned to correct noted deficiencies.  The expected completion date of all action items resulting from the audit is July, 2008.
The facility has an active accident / incident prevention program.  Each incident and near miss associated with the process area is evaluated and, if it meets pre-defined criteria, a team-based investigation is performed.  The investigation¿s purpose is to identify root and contributing causes and to make recommendations to prevent future recurrence.  The facility¿s safety department tracks investigation action items through until closure.
Employees are active in all aspects of process safety, including safe work permitting, process hazard analyses, incident investigations, mechanical integrity and management of change.  Additionally, contractors are involved in many aspects of the programs.  
Kaneka screens contractors based on safety performance before they are allowed entrance to the facility.  Employees responsible for projects involving contractors are encouraged to provide feedback to both management and the contractor on the contractor¿s overall safety performance.
E.  Five-year accident history:
The Kaneka Texas Pasadena Facility has never had, in the history of the facility, any release that reached beyond the property line or resulted in deaths on site, injuries or significant property damage on site, or any offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering-in-place, property damage or environmental damage.
F.  Emergency response program:
The facility maintains an emergency response plan that defines the steps the facility and each employee should take during an accidental release of a regulated substance.  The plan includes both evacuation and protective action procedures for employees not directly involved in the response, and actions to be taken by employees responsible for responding to and mitigating the release.  All employees are trained in the applicable emergency response procedures.

Drills and exercises are routinely conducted to test the facility¿s plans and revise the plans if necessary. 
The emergency response plan includes procedures for notifying facility personnel, including emergency response personnel, the local Channels Industry Mutual Aid (CIMA) agency, the Community Awareness Emergency Response (CAER) organization and the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  
G.  Planned changes to improve safety:
Safety is a continuously improved each year.  Budget is set aside to ensure maintenance, testing and inspection are performed as specified and deficiencies, if noted, are corrected immediately.  Examples of continuous improvement at Kaneka Texas include:
¿  Cl2 detection and monitoring systems are being installed in CPVC which meet or exceed the Chlorine Institute¿s Guidelines;
¿  New security cameras will be installed;
¿  New security gate will be installed to service CPVC and MSA units 24-hours per day; and
¿  A foam water system capable of protecting all floors of the new MSA production unit, 5-story building, is being installed to protect in the event of a simultaneous flammable release.
